awd_titl_txt: CAREER:  Large-Scale Bayesian Inverse Problems Governed by Differential and Differential-Algebraic Equations
awd_abstract_narration:
Nontechnical explanation of the project's broader significance and importance: Model-based projections of real life applications will play a central role in prediction and decision-making, in environment and climate change applications, for instance, to anticipate ice sheet contribution to sea level rise, or in the context of energy applications, to predict faults and assess dynamic stability in a power grid.  However, models are typically subject to considerable uncertainties stemming from uncertain inputs to the model (e.g., coefficient fields, constitutive laws, source terms, geometries, and initial and/or boundary conditions) as well as from noisy and limited observations. While many of these input quantities cannot be directly observed or measured, they can be inferred from observations, such as those of ice surface velocities in ice sheets. This typically leads to an extremely challenging mathematical problem. This project aims to enable the propagation of uncertainties from data/observations through inference to prediction and increase predictability of complex physical systems.  The selected driving application (i.e., the ice sheet model) for research and education activities, capture important general and complex algorithmic challenges such as large-scale, nonlinearity, time-dependence, and ill-posedness. The research will be, therefore, applicable to a broader spectrum of problems. The algorithms, mathematical findings and open source codes will be shared through peer reviewed journal papers, and presentations at conferences and workshops.
 
Technical description of the project: Bayesian inversion facilitates the integration of data with complex physics-based models to quantify and reduce uncertainties in model predictions. This opens the door to more advanced capabilities for prediction and decision-making under uncertainty.  However, the algorithmic developments for Bayesian inversion are subject to several challenges. For instance, characterizing the posterior distributions of parameters or predictions inevitably requires repeated evaluations of (possibly) large-scale and complex forward models governed by differential equations.  In addition, the posterior distribution has a complex structure stemming from the presence of possibly nonlinear forward models and heterogeneous sources of data. To overcome these computational challenges, it is essential to exploit problem structure (e.g., derivatives and local sensitivity of the data with respect to parameters). The objectives of this proposal is to conduct exploratory work in addressing the mathematical and computational barriers in solving large-scale Bayesian inverse problems governed by differential equations. Developing mathematically rigorous and computationally efficient and robust methods in the context of statistical inference has the potential of transformative research in the field of modern computational inverse problems. In particular, the PI and her student will work on the following vertically-integrated research areas: (i) scalable algorithms for large-scale inverse problems (here the focus will be on second derivative (i.e., Hessian) approximations for inverse problems and on developing efficient preconditioners for inexact Newton-Krylov systems to increase the computational efficiency of inverse solvers), and (ii) uncertainty quantification in high dimensions (here the focus will be on building Hessian- and reduced order model-based methods for efficient posterior exploration in high dimensions). The proposed research requires an interdisciplinary perspective, namely it brings together applied mathematics, scientific computing and statistics.

por.por_cntn:
Under this NSF grant, new mathematical formulations, algorithms, and software frameworks were developed that enable solution of high dimensional Bayesian inverse problems governed by differential equations. 

Project outcomes that address the Research component of this grant:

Intellectual Merit: Upon discretization of the unknown infinite-dimensional parameter field, the solution of the Bayesian inference problem typically takes the form of a very high-dimensional posterior probability density function (pdf) that assigns to any candidate set of parameter fields our belief (expressed as a probability) that a member of this candidate set is the "true" parameter field that gave rise to the observed data. Sampling this posterior pdf to compute, for example, the mean and covariance of the parameters presents tremendous challenges, since not only is it high-dimensional, but evaluating the pdf at any point in parameter space requires a forward simulation and millions of such evaluations may be required to obtain statistics of interest using state-of-the-art Markov chain Monte Carlo methods. The PI's work focused on finding approximations of the Hessian(-applies) (of the underlying optimization objective) and dimension reduction techniques, i.e., on methods that will ease the computational complexity when solving inverse problems governed by complex models. A secondary avenue that led to fruitful results was to account for secondary (additional uncertainties) in Bayesian Inverse Problems and Optimal Experimental Design. Several publications and two PhD theses resulted from this research.

Broader Impact: The algorithms, mathematical findings, and open-source codes have been shared through peer reviewed journal papers, and presentations at conferences and workshops. Perhaps the most notable presentation was a plenary talk at the SIAM Conference on Uncertainty Quantification (UQ24). In collaboration with UT Austin and MIT, the PI also worked on an open-source software framework incorporating a suite of advanced Bayesian inversion algorithms. hIPPYlib-MUQ was released in 2022, and it is being used as a research and teaching tool by the PIs group and others. 

Project outcomes that address the Educational component of this grant:

An important component of this project involved integrating state-of-the-art research with education. The following education activities have been proposed: 

1. New graduate level classes at UC Merced: During Fall 2021, the PI has taught a Special topics class on "Inverse Problems: Systematic Integration of Data with Models under Uncertainty".

2. Contribute to the undergraduate curriculum: The PI served on the curriculum committee for undergraduate classes, contributed with projects to the mathematical modeling class, and since 2023 the PI is the Applied Mathematics Undergraduate Chair.

3. Undergraduate internship at UC Merced: The PI recruited and worked with several Applied Mathematics Undergraduate students.

4. High school students workshop at UC Merced: In 2022, the PI co-organized the first Applied Mathematics High School Math Challenge at UC Merced. This was a two weeklong event for local high school students who wished to gain a deeper understanding of mathematics and research experience. 

5. Tutorials and short courses: The PI has co-organized several workshops during the lifetime of this grant. The most notable are as follows:

  • The "2018 Gene Golub SIAM Summer School" (2018)
  • "Women in Inverse Problems" workshop at the Banff International Research Station for Mathematical Innovation and Discovery (2021)
  • Minitutorial on "Inverse Problems: Integrating Data with PDE-based Models Under Uncertainty" at the SIAM Conference on Mathematics of Data Science (2022)
  • ``Women in Inverse Problems" workshop at the SIAM Conference on Optimization (2023)
  • Led the establishment of the new Northern and Central California Section of SIAM and became its chair (2024)
  •  The "1st SIAM Northern and Central California Sectional Conference".

6. Mentoring: The PI has mentored three postdoctoral researchers, three graduate students (two graduated and are currently postdoctoral researchers at National Laboratories), mentored several undergraduate students, set on several PhD committees (within the Applied Mathematics and Engineering departments), and served as the UC Merced SIAM Student Chapter Advisor for eight years. To assess mentoring practices, as discussed and promised in this NSF CAREER proposal, the PI collaborated with the Students Assessing Teaching and Learning (SATAL) Program. The results have been extremely insightful and showed a successful and fruitful mentorship.

In terms of professional growth, the PI has received tenure and has been promoted to Associate Professor and recently has applied for full professor promotion. In addition, she enjoyed recognition from her research community (e.g., became Associate Editor for SIAM / ASA Journal on Uncertainty Quantification and for SIAM Review), and was invited to deliver a plenary talk at SIAM Conference on Uncertainty Quantification (UQ24). 

Looking forward, the PI plans continue the research related to large-scale Bayesian Inverse Problems by building on the results obtained under this grant. The PI also looks forward to continue working on diversity-related projects and participating in education activities (such as the ones listed above) in the future. 

The PI would like to express her gratitude to NSF for the financial support via this CAREER grant.
